verses.text: Then David came to Nob, to Ahimelech the priest. And Ahimelech came trembling to meet David and said to him, "Why are you alone, and no one is with you?"
verses.comment: Nob was a city of priests. Ahimelech's fear is emphasized in the Hebrew.

verses.text: And David said to Ahimelech the priest, "The king has charged me with a matter and said to me, 'Let no one know anything about the matter on which I am sending you, or with which I have charged you.' I have directed the young men to a certain place."
verses.comment: David here does not reveal the true reason for his visit, but tells Ahimelech he is on a secret mission from Saul.

verses.text: Now then, what do you have on hand? Give me five loaves of bread, or whatever is here."
verses.comment: Jesus refers to this event in Matthew 12:3-4.

verses.text: And the priest answered David, "There is no ordinary bread on hand, but there is holy bread—if the young men have kept themselves from women."
verses.comment: Holy bread refers to the showbread reserved for priests (Lev. 24:5-9).

verses.text: And David answered the priest, "Truly, women have been kept from us as always when I go on a journey. The vessels of the young men are holy even when it is an ordinary journey. How much more today will their vessels be holy?"
verses.comment: By 'vessels,' David is referring to the bodies of his men (ceremonial cleanness).

verses.text: So the priest gave him holy bread; for there was no bread there but the bread of the Presence, which is taken from before the LORD, to be replaced by hot bread on the day it is taken away.
verses.comment: Bread of the Presence is also called the showbread, changed weekly (Lev. 24:8-9).

verses.text: Now a certain man of the servants of Saul was there that day, detained before the LORD. His name was Doeg the Edomite, the chief of Saul's herdsmen.
verses.comment: Doeg becomes important in the next chapter (Ps. 52 title).

verses.text: And David said to Ahimelech, "Is there not here on hand a spear or a sword? For I brought neither my sword nor my weapons with me, because the king's matter required haste."
verses.comment: David requests a weapon, claiming he left hurriedly.

verses.text: And the priest said, "The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you struck down in the Valley of Elah, is here, wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you will take that, take it, for there is no other except it here." And David said, "There is none like it; give it to me."
verses.comment: David receives Goliath’s sword, which had been placed as a memorial.

verses.text: And David arose and fled that day from Saul, and went to Achish the king of Gath.
verses.comment: Gath was a Philistine city; see Ps. 34 (superscription) for David's experience there.

verses.text: And the servants of Achish said to him, "Is this not David the king of the land? Did they not sing to one another about him in dances, saying, 'Saul has slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands'?"
verses.comment: Reference to Israelite victory songs (1 Sam. 18:7).

verses.text: And David took these words to heart and was very much afraid of Achish king of Gath.
verses.comment: See Psalm 56 (title) for David's thoughts in Gath.

verses.text: So he changed his behavior before them and pretended to be insane in their hands. He made marks on the doors of the gate and let his saliva run down his beard.
verses.comment: David feigns madness to avoid harm.

verses.text: Then Achish said to his servants, "Look, you see the man is mad. Why have you brought him to me?"
verses.comment: Achish responds to David's feigned insanity.

verses.text: "Do I lack madmen, that you have brought this fellow to behave as a madman in my presence? Shall he come into my house?"
verses.comment: Achish sarcastically notes that he has enough madmen already.
